course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Thermodynamics and Statistical Physics
course.description: Laws of thermodynamics, entropy, thermodynamic relations, free energy; elementary statistical mechanics: Maxwell-Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac statistics; elementary transport theory; applications to physical systems.

reviews.comment_content:
Topics: (1) Basic thermodynamics; the first law, ideal gas, etc. (2) The second law & entropy (3) Thermodynamic identity (4) Heat engine, Carnot cycle (5) Thermodynamic potentials  (6) Boltzmann Statistics (7) Quantum Statistics

It is basically just Ch.1 - 7 of the textbook, with Ch.4 more or less skipped. It is very standard for an introductory course on thermal physics, and I especially like this balanced treatment between classical thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.

The textbook (Schroeder) is a good one. It is in general very understandable and "reader-friendly". The author's writing style make the book kind of like a "Griffiths" in thermodynamics. If you have the time, I highly suggest you to read through the textbook.

Unfortunately though, Schroeder did not do a very good job on quantum statistics (ch.7) like the rest of the book and make the subject mysteriously difficult to understand from his explanation. Therefore, I would suggest you to obtain a secondary text for the quantum statistics part. I personally uses Stowe's "Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics", which is readily available from the library and is on about the same level & scope as Schroeder (so it can also be used as a supplement to other topics).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Cheung is a standard one. He mostly just read aloud the PowerPoint in class, and sometime do some explanation on the whiteboard (especially for the stat mech part).

I can tell he has a good altitude toward teaching. But unfortunately, due to his limited English proficiency and teaching skills, I really can't say his teaching is good at all. But at least he did try his best to be helpful, for example, he often upload a lot of supplementary material on Canvas and give hints to the homework problems, and he replies email inquiry at an extremely fast rate.

For the course material, although I always think teaching physics with PowerPoint is simply ridiculous, the PowerPoint slides used by this course are so far the only one I found to be acceptable for a physics course. They explain things quite clearly and often offer alternative derivation to some of the major result in the textbook. The exams are based more on the content of the PowerPoint, so I suggest you to read through them to get used to  the alternative methods and notations, when studying for the exam.

The TA will work through several problems (and go through the homework) during the tutorial session.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework Assignments 25.0%
Mid-Term Exam 35.0%
Final Examination 40.0%

There is also a PRS bonus, which can be obtained from answering PRS questions during the lecture throughout the whole semester (there are not many of them though). The bonus can count for a maximum of 2%. The bonus won't normally included in your overall score, but if your score happened to be near the cut-off of a sub-grade, then the bonus points will be used to raise your final grade by one sub-grade.

I think the grading is fair enough, and it provides you quite some chance to get a good grade by including this PRS bonus system and having a 25% homework component.

I am not too sure about the grade distribution, but here are some statistics of the exams:

Midterm: mean 72.3 SD 1x (I don't remember)
Final: mean 44.4 SD 2x

The professor tended to make the midterm too easy, and there will be quite a lot of people scored nearly full-marks. To make up for that, the final was much more difficult.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is one homework assignment every week, which contains about 1-2 textbook problems. They can be very easily solved within 15 minutes, if you understand the material. But they can be quite stressful if you are behind in class, especially after the midterm period when you are way too busy to study at all.

For the exams, it is very important to get a clear conceptual understanding of every topic. The exams won't ask you to do some very sophisticated calculation, but rather, they often ask you to re-derive something that is in the text. (The final essentially ask you to reproduce all the major results in Ch.7) So it is a good idea to go through all the derivation in the textbook yourself.

Also, Dr. Cheung will post a selected set of problems from the textbook for each chapter on canvas, they are also very helpful for studying for the exams.

reviews.author: Weewee
reviews.title: The textbook and lecture notes are great, the lecturer not so much
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm:
1. Equipartition theorem
2. Ideal gas law (much more in depth than PHYS1112, more proving)
3. Heat engines, heat pumps
4. Entropy, definition of temperature
5. Equilibrium states

Final:
1. Maxwell Relations
2. Chemical Potential
3. Van der Waals model for real gas
4. Proving equipartition theorem
5. Partition functions
6. Quantum statistics
7. Density of states
8. Degenerate electron gases
9. Black body radiation
10. Bose-Einstein Condensates
11. Debye Solids

Everything is based on "An Introduction to Thermal Physics" by Daniel V. Schroeder. Chapter 1.7, 4.3-4.4, 5.4-5.6, and 8 are skipped, otherwise we would die. A suggested textbook is "Concepts in Thermal Physics" by Blundell and Blundell. Both excellent textbooks with useful exercises and solutions online.

As you can see, final is more chur than midterm.

I am a LIFS student, and I took this course alongside PHYS2022, so it is easy to see that the prerequisite is quite unnecessary.

It is recommended that at the very least you have studied MATH2011/2023 Multivariable Calculus, and remember some concepts like integration by parts and Taylor series from MATH1014. These things will appear all the time.

Revisiting the thermodynamics from PHYS1112 is optional, because you would be proving everything anyways.

There will be some strange integrals, but don't worry, the solutions would be given (or maybe you would be able to solve it by yourself if you still remember what you learnt in MATH2023).

I think the content is interesting, and the textbook made it seem even more interesting. The mathematics involved is suffering, but as long as you do all the exercises in the textbook that are related to math, you should be able to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I never attended the lectures, so I think the professor is excellent. His lecture note slides are actually very concise with some extra necessary information for proving some thermodynamic equations (like what is the internal energy of a degenerate electron gas at 0 K).

The textbook is excellent, very easy to read, makes the entire course much more fun. The solutions to all the exercises can be found online as well, so if you don't get full marks in homework then you should reflect on your life (all from textbook).

reviews.comment_workload:
1 homework every week with several problems from main textbook. So essentially 0 workload. However, if you want to get good marks in the exam, it is strongly recommended to at the very least, do all the exercises in the main textbook (Introduction to Thermal). The midterm past papers are useful and doable. Solutions can be found if you look hard enough. I couldn't find any solutions for final past papers, and they are hard as fuck. However, this year the final is a bit easier (yay).

If you really want to secure an A, then select some relevant exercises from the suggested textbook as well (Concepts in Thermal). Other than that, I hope that your IQ is high enough to find some relationships between the exam questions and the questions that you had done.

reviews.author: PeterLin
reviews.title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Physics
reviews.comment_content:
Textbook for the course: Daniel V. Schroeder, An Introduction to Thermal Physics, 1st Ed.
The course covered the above textbook except chapter 1.7, 4.3, 4.4, 5.4-5.6 and 8.

The course is informative, starting from basic thermodynamic laws to the Bose-Einstein Condensation, which may serve as a prerequisite for the solid state physics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor uses his own ppt, it's basically a simplified version of the content on the textbook. He mainly reads through the content with some necessary derivation. He is open to questions. But I think preview/revision is needed because it is not easy to catch up with him if you get stuck or forgot the material in previous lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:

30% open book midterm exam (no electronic device)
40% open book final exam (no electronic device)

midterm (full: 30, chap 1-4)
Mean: 18.23 High: 28 Low: 0

final (full: 120, chap 1-4 and chap 5-7(emphasise))
Mean: 64.01 High: 116 Low: 17

As mentioned in the "workload" section, the mean for homework is very high. In midterm and final, some questions are similar to the homework and questions in the book. Also, in final and midterm there're a few "tough problems" (like infinite summations or multiple integrals involved, a lot of calculus), resulting in the low mean.

I get full for hw, nearly high in mt and 96 in final and result in A-. Because of the lack of statistics, I don't know the grade distribution, but I don't think it is as good as previous years (from previous comments).
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 12 homeworks (selected from the textbook) with three questions in each hw. I think they are not trivial (if you compare them with other questions in the textbook that are not selected) and it takes some time to complete. However, the mean is very high and I guess it's because there's access to the selected solution to the textbook.
To understand the content well, I went through the textbook several times.

reviews.author: H_Barnes
reviews.title: Quite a rush
reviews.comment_content: From the basics to quantum statistics: Laws of thermodynamics, entropy, thermodynamic relations, Carnot cycle, free energy to Maxwell-Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac statistics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Cheung tries his best to explain the materials in the lectures but his spoken English is not very good so sometimes I get confused before I truly understand his words. But revisions before and after a lecture helps quite a lot to comprehend and catch up with the class. As a natively-Cantonese-speaking Hongkonger, Dr Cheung is passionate to answer students question in Cantonese/Mandarin during the break or after the lecture. He also tries to interact with us by asking us simple questions and giving classwork with discussions with each other. His notes are easy to understand: like main points are highlighted and details with examples are given for some key concept. Overall his teaching is quite good. The tutorial session is to explain the homework given with full solutions given. It makes us easier to understand the materials and prepare well before the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not bad.
The mean of the midterm exam is high (~95/100) because it is straightforward and easy to handle. So Dr. Cheung guarantees us that all of us will get a pass grade if we all attend the final exam and submit all homework, due to our great performance in midterm. The final exam is somewhat harder than the midterm and the mean is around 65/100 so in the long run quite a number of us get a A grade. Those with below mean results obtain a C range. So overall it is fair in grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
The homework given is not too difficult so it is no big deal.
As we study this course within one and half a month, it is quite rush to learn and understand, like we need to comprehend one chapter within a week to catch up with the class. So all the effort needed is to study before and after each lecture. Then overall the workload is not high.

reviews.author: sadness
reviews.comment_content:
係midterm作分界線, midterm前係classical thermodynamics

1. Energy in Thermal Physics
Ideal gas, first law of thermodynamics, equipartition theorem, free expansion

2. The second law
introduction to probability and statistics, multiplicity, microstate, macrostate, Einstein model in solid, Stirling 's Approximation, Sackur-Tetrode Equation

3. Entropy and temperature
Third law of thermodynamics, , two-state paramagnet, magnetization

4. Heat Engine and Refrigerator, Carnot Cycle.

Midterm 之後會教free energies同phase transformation, 之後就係classical statistical mechanics + Quantum Statistical Mechanics

5. Free Energy and Chemical Thermodynamics
Thermodynamic relations, Helmholtz free energy, Gibbs free energy, phase diagram, The Clausius-Clapeyron Relation, The van der Waals Model, phase transfomation

6. Boltzmann Statistics
The Boltzmann Factor, degeneracy, Canonical ensemble, partition function, Maxwell speed distribution

7. Quantum Statistics
The Gibbs Factor, grand partition function, grand canonical ensemble, Bosons and Fermions, Pauli exclusion Principle, density of state, Fermi-Dirac Distribution,
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. 上堂大部份時間係照讀, 但佢唔會被書本的內容限制，間唔中會問一D同本書無關或者其他相當有啟發性既問題, 例如粒子不作3D移動但2D又如何? 假如粒子以近乎光速移動又如何? 最重要係, final exam係會考呢d textbook冇但上堂有教既野

講野速度慢, 但教書速度快, 內容係pack得幾多, 上堂好多slide都係跳出黎1-2分鐘左右, 即係你聽完佢上堂通常都唔明佢講乜, lecture notes好大程度係copy textbook.

個人意見係, 如果你走堂, 睇書睇notes都未必明. 雖然你上左堂都唔明, 但起碼知道邊D係重點, 之後睇書都會比較容易掌握
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Online Quiz
冇功課但有online quiz, 要上一個system完成題目, 共有7個quiz, 每次5條題目, 都係textbook抽出黎, 每個人每一次做同一條題目, d數字都唔同, 不過可以做無限次, 係deadline前只會計得分最高果次

20% midterm
同online quiz既題目好相似, 唔太難, mean有50幾60%
40% final exam
6條題目, 3條係online quiz題目, 另外3條分別係3種distribution: Maxwell Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein, Fermi-Dirac, blackbody radiation, Debye Theory of Solid

10% Project
題目係travelling salesman problem, 每位學生隨機抽20點coordinate, 計算最短距離行哂20點而唔重覆, 要寫program計optimization, Monte-Carlo Method去推算最短既path. 最後交返1-2頁既report, 有abstract, introduction, data, conclusion

上堂答問題有分, 答1題總分+1%, 最高可得10%
reviews.comment_workload: Workload唔算重, quiz, project, midterm都比人拎分, 只要3個midterm above mean已經夠合格

reviews.author: ChuaWanZhen
reviews.title: The organization of the teaching content is very good
reviews.comment_content: I think the content designed for this course is quite good as most of us that took this course are new to statistical mechanics. It provides us a new approach towards physical systems. However, towards the end of the course, the part on quantum statistics can be very hard. I found some difficulty in mastering it as the integration and the application of concepts on the physical systems can be hard. Also, there is limited time in mastering it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Cheung is a responsible guy. He tries his best to teach this course even though he has some difficulties in explaining using English. However, I can see that he puts a lot of effort. So, don't just judge him by his English.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very good. I think the professor has such a soft heart and he is very lenient in marking our papers. I got the answer wrong but he saw that I used the correct concept in deriving a relation, and he gave me full marks for that question. He mainly focused on our concepts and only deduct a few marks if we get the answer wrong. I think the difficulty for the finals is reasonable as the problems can be rather tricky.
reviews.comment_workload: He would only assigned one or two problems weekly. The problems for the midterms and exams are mainly proofs, not much calculation is required. So, be sure to know how to derive the relations and understand them well. You need a lot of practice to master the concepts especially quantum statistics (There is a few physical systems and they can be rather confusing). So, be sure to go through them again and again and work out the questions given during the tutorial. The TA is also a nice and friendly guy.
